utterances: Let's go next to - this is Jim, and Jim is on the line with us from Kansas City.
Yeah, I just have one really quick comment.
And I just - I really appreciate the kindness and graciousness and the patience that he had with Julia.
And I still enjoy watching the show just for the chemistry.
And you are a gracious man, and thank you so much for the show.
OK.
Thank you.
Thank you, but you know, I met Julia in 1960, you know?
I came here at the end of 1959.
And a few months after, and I met James Beard as well as Craig Claiborne (unintelligible) the New York Time.
The kind of trinity of cooking, you know, James Beard, Julia Child and Craig Claiborne - just to show you how small the food world was, extremely small at that time.
So I became friends with Julia, and then I have been teaching at Boston University for 30 years, and she lived in Cambridge, of course, so we cook together a great deal.
We met.
We eat together.
We had fun.
And then we started doing shows, so she became a very dear friend.
Here's an email about her from Nancy in Charlotte.
The best thing I learned from a cooking show was many years ago from Julia Child's ""The French Chef."" I learned it's OK to drop a duck on the floor, pick it up, clean it off, and continue cooking.
Things happen.
Food does not have to be perfect.
Yes, it's right.
I wonder, did you see the movie ""Julie and Julia""?
Yes, I did.
Actually, I lecture on it a couple of time.
The movie started in 1949 and finished in 1961 when she published ""Mastering the Art of French Cooking,"" so it's a great deal of her time in France.
And Julia used to kid me that we started cooking together because she came to France in 1949 and I went into apprenticeship in 1949.
Of course, I was 13 years old.
But the time depicted at the time was very accurate, and I thought it was terrific.
And I think that Meryl Streep was just amazing.
She (unintelligible) Julia in that movie.
I don't know how she did it, but a great movie.
Let's see if we get Tiffany in.
Tiffany calling from Castle Rock in Colorado.
Hi.
Thank you for taking my call.
I wanted to say thank you.
My husband and I both came from a background of cooking, and we were looking for a custard one time and just couldn't do it.
We record your show almost religiously and came across one at a time when you had made a custard in it.
It turned out to be the best thing in our dinner party that night.
Well, great.
When it's good like that, you don't give me credit.
You say this is what I brought.
That's my recipe.
That's the way it works.
Only if it's not too good, you say, I don't know.
I took the recipe from that guy there, you know?
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
No, it was great.
Your technique helped us figure out how to keep the eggs from overcooking.
It was great.
We really appreciate and love watching you.
That's the word from the Tampa Bay Host Committee, which produced this video for convention volunteers.
(SOUNDBITE OF TAMPA BAY HOST COMMITTEE VIDEO)
(Singing) ...(Unintelligible)
Thanks very much for the call, Tiffany.
Let's see if we can go next to this email from Curry(ph) in Buffalo, New York: I've been a fan of Jacques for many years, enjoyed the many different shows he had on PBS.
The very best ones were the ones he did with Julia.
Those shows were hilarious.
The tremendous friendship they had was apparent on every show, coupled with the great talent in the kitchen.
It will never be equaled.
Thanks, Jacques, for sharing your knowledge and your expertise.
Excuse me, that was Donna from Buffalo, New York.
And...
Thank you.
And, you know, the interesting part in that, like I did that new series for ""Essential Pepin"" now, and the new series that I do at KQED in San Francisco is 26 show of half-hour.
Usually, when we do the series - and my daughter did a few show with me.
My granddaughter even did a couple of show with me.

And usually, I mean, when you come, you have the recipe with you, or at least you may change them a little bit along the way, but you have the manuscript, so the back kitchen and all that know where we're going.
When we did that series with Julia, we had no recipe.
We discuss about, OK, let's do stew one day or let's do eggs or let's do whatever, but we didn't have actual recipe.
So we started cooking like you cook with friend or with your spouse, you know?
So I'm thinking one thing or another and cooking together.
Jacques Pepin, thanks very much for your time.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And for a look at the big picture, we're joined - as we always are every Monday - by NPR's senior Washington editor Ron Elving.
Hi, Ron.
Good to be with you, Madeleine.
Ron, people are already voting in Texas, even though the primary's not until next week.
And so what are we seeing?
What we're seeing is an enormous outpouring of voter interest in these choices in both parties.
In the Republican Party, voting has doubled in some of the big counties, tripled in some of the biggest counties, even gone up sevenfold in Harris County.
That's where Houston is.
But you know what?
Those numbers are beggared by the increases in early voting on the Democrat side.
Where sevenfold would be small.
Some counties, including Harris, is already up by tenfold.
This is just the early voting, where people go to special locations and mail in ballots as well.
It is not the actual primary, which will take place on March 4th, although all these votes do count.
Well, let's talk about their various tactics, the two candidates on the Democratic side - Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama.
You know, Ron, when they debated last week in Texas at the end of that debate it almost sounded like Hillary Clinton was saying goodbye.
She said, you know, no matter what happens I'll be fine.
I'm just worried about the American people.
But then over the weekend it seemed like her tone changed.
And let's listen first to Senator Clinton after a rally in Cincinnati on Saturday.
(Soundbite of Clinton rally)
Shame on you, Barack Obama.
It is time you ran a campaign consistent with your messages in public.
And so she sounds a little angry there.
And in this tape cut that we have from yesterday she sounds not only angry but sarcastic.
Let's listen.
(Soundbite of Clinton rally)
Let's get unified, the sky will open…
(Soundbite of laughter)
…the light will come down…
(Soundbite of laughter)
…celestial choirs will be singing…
(Soundbite of laughter)
…and everyone will now we should do the right thing and the world will be perfect.
(Soundbite of applause)
Ron Elving, is that a deliberate campaign strategy or is she really, really frustrated with the sense that, you know, people are looking at Barack Obama as a pie-in-the-sky candidate?
I'm sure there must be some of both in this, Madeleine.

I think that on one hand the campaign, at least some of the people in Hillary Clinton's campaign, have felt such enormous frustration with the popularity of Barack Obama, with what they see as the media's preference for Barack Obama, and the media doing everything it can to support him and promote him and knock down their candidate.
So she's frustrated.
Her campaign is frustrated.
And they have calculated they must make a change.

But I think in this one particular incident she risks going too far and offending people who, while they haven't decided yet between the two candidates, do see some appeal in Barack Obama's message and don't find it attractive to see the way she's characterizing it.
Yeah.
It seems a little risky to go after hope.
But after losing 11 voting events in a row, risk taking looks pretty necessary to the Clinton campaign.
All right.
As you said earlier, the action is on the Democratic side, but let's turn for a moment to the Republican side.
And John McCain obviously the front runner, Mike Huckabee still in the race.
And we're talking Texas.
Ron Paul, he is from Texas.
Does he stand a chance at all?
Ron Paul's campaign will get some votes in Ohio.
It certainly will get some votes in his home state of Texas.
He's not going to win any of these primaries, as indeed he has not been a factor in the primaries up to now.
And he has shifted to defending his own seat in Congress.
He's got a strong opponent in his primary there in Texas.
The bigger question in Texas is going to be how well John McCain does in holding down the vote of Mike Huckabee.
There are still a lot of people -including social conservatives, evangelical Christians and others - who don't feel John McCain is sufficiently committed to their causes yet.
And they're out there voting for Mike Huckabee and making a point that unless John McCain moves their way, they're going to jump ship, either to vote third party in November or to just stay home.
